question: Ten chairs are numbered as 1 to 10. Three women and two men wish to occupy one chair each. First the women choose the chairs marked 1 to 6, then the men choose the chairs from the remaining. The number of possible ways is
explanation: Women choose and arrange themselves in 3 chairs out of 6: ${}^{6}P_3$.

The correct answer option D (${}^{6}P_3 \times {}^{4}P_2$) suggests the men are choosing from a set of 4 chairs. This implies the 'remaining' refers to the chairs 7, 8, 9, 10. If men were choosing from any empty chair, it would be ${}^{7}P_2$. Given the option, the interpretation is men occupy chairs 7-10.
